Legal_Issue: Whether Vivat's pocket stitching designs are confusingly similar to Levi's DOUBLE ARCUATE trademark
Procedural_Stage: Appeal before the Trademarks Opposition Board (TMOB)
Evidence_Assessment: Both marks share a double arch-double stitch design; visual differences noted but outweighed by similarities; evidence of Levi's well-known mark and limited third-party use due to enforcement
Burden_of_Proof: Vivat failed to prove no likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Levi's established market presence and enforcement history
Legal_Rule: Section 6 of the Trade-marks Act defines confusion as the likelihood that consumers would infer the goods associated with two trademarks are from the same source
Standard_of_Review: Likelihood of confusion under statutory framework
Grounds_for_Claim: Potential consumer confusion due to similarity with Levi's registered DOUBLE ARCUATE design
Outcome_on_Merits: Applications refused on merits due to risk of confusion
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and application of confusion test
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: TMOB conducted review with consideration of evidence and legal provisions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Design similarity, distinctiveness of Levi's mark, market recognition, third-party usage patterns
Applicant_Challenge: Vivat's attempt to register similar stitching design
Defendant_Response: Vivat failed to demonstrate absence of confusion
Evidence_Type: Visual design comparison, market evidence, third-party usage data
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of registration of confusingly similar mark
Authority: Trade-marks Act, Canadian Intellectual Property Office (CIPO) framework
Claimant_Status: Levi as opposer, holder of registered trademark
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Likelihood of confusion with prior registered mark
Applicable_Process: Trademark opposition process under Canadian law
